hero.title: AI Skills for Job-Market Readiness
takeaway: Employers increasingly expect graduates to use AI tools for research, analysis, communication, and workflow automation.
The strongest preparation combines shared foundational AI literacy with discipline-specific practice tailored to job family needs.

coreSkills.title: AI Literacy and Model Awareness
coreSkills.description: Understand what modern AI can and cannot do, including common failure modes, bias risks, and confidence calibration.

coreSkills.title: Prompting and Task Framing
coreSkills.description: Translate ambiguous goals into clear prompts, constraints, and evaluation criteria to produce useful outputs consistently.

coreSkills.title: Verification and Critical Evaluation
coreSkills.description: Fact-check AI outputs against trusted sources, evaluate reasoning quality, and identify hallucinations before reuse.

coreSkills.title: Data and Workflow Fluency
coreSkills.description: Use spreadsheets, lightweight automation, and AI-assisted analysis to accelerate repetitive tasks and decision cycles.

coreSkills.title: Ethics, Policy, and Responsible Use
coreSkills.description: Apply privacy, copyright, security, and fairness principles when using AI in academic and professional contexts.

nonTechnical.label: Non-technical
skills: AI-assisted writing, summarization, and stakeholder communication
Customer and market insight extraction from qualitative data
Responsible use of AI for documentation, planning, and reporting
Human-in-the-loop review for tone, compliance, and brand safety

technical.label: Technical
skills: AI coding copilots for prototyping, testing, and refactoring
Data pipeline literacy and model performance monitoring
Security, privacy, and governance practices for AI-enabled systems

highStakes.label: High-stakes
skills: Evidence-based verification for decisions affecting people or safety
Bias detection and mitigation in sensitive workflows
Escalation protocols when AI output uncertainty is high
